business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the minister to the words of Dr Ken Henry, the head of the Treasurer's tax task force, in the Senate GST committee. He said:

question.para: We have not attempted to develop a model which would be capable of analysing this package, and that is really for the reason I have already indicated. No such model exists anywhere else—nothing that we would say is quite up to the task, given the complexity of the package.

Is the minister aware that such modelling is in fact possible and that even the Prime Minister's preferred modeller, Mr Chris Murphy, has provided information to the tax inquiry, along with Professor Dixon, about shifts in the economy in terms of employment levels, something that Dr Henry denied was possible? Why has Treasury consistently refused to investigate the wider ramifications of this tax package?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I was at that hearing, Senator George Campbell—and I suspect that you were not at that hearing—when evidence was given by Dr Ken Henry. Senators should be aware that Dr Ken Henry was extremely supportive of the package—not surprisingly, given the way the package was constructed. He was subjected to considerable questioning by the Labor Party on this package; the questions were not very good and I think they left the hearings feeling rather bruised, and quite rightly so. We have made it very clear that modelling shows that the tax package—
—What modelling?

—Let me quote the Labor Party's preferred modeller of choice, the so-called Dixon model. Before Professor Dixon accepted the assumptions which were fed in by the Labor Party, before he accepted the assumptions which the non-government members of the committee insisted he feed into his model, even he, the Labor Party modeller of choice, said he believed that it would have a beneficial effect on employment in the economy to the tune of, if I remember correctly, some 30,000 people.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Would senators on my left please cease shouting.

—If we leave the modelling and the evidence from Professor Dixon, Access Economics in their a AEM model forecast report of December 1998 indicated that, as a result of the tax package, there would be an additional 190,000 jobs created in the long term. The research undertaken by the Melbourne Institute shows that the tax changes could increase the number of jobs by 50,000. So there is plenty of evidence on the record. Plenty of evidence has been presented to the Senate committee which shows that the tax package has very beneficial effects on the Australian economy and employment.

answer.para: It is a great pity that Senator George Campbell did not listen closely to the evidence Dr Henry gave to that committee when he explained the assumptions behind that particular question the senator asked me. The evidence that is on the record, the evidence that has been produced by a wide variety of other models, including evidence presented to the Senate committee by Professor Dixon, shows that this package is very good for jobs. It is very surprising that the Labor Party refuses to support this package. I would have thought that, as a party that holds itself out as the representative of employees—which is of course untrue; it is the representative of trade union bosses and trade union interests—it would have strongly supported this tax package.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, it is a fact that Treasury did not conduct any modelling in terms of this package. Why is the government so reluctant to have the tax package examined properly? Is it because Mr Costello does not want the truth about the GST to get out?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Again Senator Campbell's question contains a very misleading statement. Senator Campbell meant to say that the employment effects of the tax package were not modelled. I suspect that is what he meant to say. I have pointed out to Senator George Campbell that there is a range of other models around, all of which show that this tax package is very good for the economy and very good for jobs.

—My question without notice is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. The coalition government is strongly committed to fostering the growth of small business. How will the coalition's small business initiatives make the economy work better and improve living standards for all Australians? Minister, are you aware of any alternative policy proposals and what would be the impact if these were implemented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —There can be no doubt at all that our tax package is the best possible news that small business could have.
—They don't believe you.

—It is interesting that you say that, Senator Cook, because it just shows that you still attend the branch meetings and you won't even read the newspapers. According to the Yellow Pages small business index, 80 per cent of Australian small businesses want the Australian taxation system reformed. We would like to have 100 per cent, but I will settle for 80. They know all the benefits that are there. Of course, a lot of people have had a view on this subject over the years—the ramshackle nature of that taxation system. Who said this:

answer.para: Australian governments have known for years that the country's tax system was unfair, antiquated and almost unworkable.

Do you know who said it? It was the ALP. They published a booklet called The Guide to Tax Reform and they ran ads in 1985 saying just that. In other words, they are monumental hypocrites. They know it.

Of course, what is very interesting is that they know that small business is the engine of jobs. But they are not really interested in creating new jobs; they want to hang on to union jobs. That is the fundamental difference between the parties. We want to assist small business. It is very interesting that in their heart of hearts and even in public people like Gareth Evans and now Senator Cook have come out endorsing the tax reform proposals. Bob Hogg was running the show for a number of years. Once he is freed of the shackles of the union movement and is able to actually tell it as it is, he gets out there and says, `Support the tax package; allow the Telstra bill to go through.'

Do you remember Peter Duncan, Madam President? He was not just your average Labor hack. Peter Duncan was from the left wing of the Labor Party and he was a minister in the Labor government. At the time Peter Duncan said things like this:

. . . as all my colleagues realise, the democratic nature of the Labor Party means that its policies are decided upon by the Party as a whole after extensive debate throughout our branches and affiliated unions.

In other words, he was a wholly owned subsidiary like the rest of the team. But what has happened now? This is a very instructive tale because it shows what happens when people get out into the real world, when they are not actually bound hand and foot by their union masters. Peter Duncan started up a little company called Dine-out Victoria Square Pty Ltd, and he had the temerity to actually employ non-union labour—a criminal offence, as we all know. So they dragged him off to the Industrial Relations Commission.

It is not only sad that Peter Duncan is singled out for that sort of treatment, but also what happens is that small businesses get a letter from the Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union saying this sort of thing, `On behalf of the union, I enclose a log of claims and demand that within seven days you will observe the wages and conditions of employment set out in the log or we will take you to court.'

Do you know what the log of claims says? It demands weekly wages of between $1,000 and $2,500 a week, a $200 superannuation contribution a week, a 30-hour working week 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. only, a 40 per cent casual loading, a one-hour meal break every 4 hours, triple time for overtime and public holidays, 100 days sick leave per year and eight weeks annual leave with a 50 per cent leave loading.

Madam President, I ask you, who do these people think they are: ALP senators? It is appalling. They want all the money and they do not want to do anything for it. They will tell small business, `Unless you sign on to an utterly preposterous and ludicrous ambit claim, we will take you to the Industrial Relations Commission and we will ruin your businesses.' That is the penalty you pay for not toeing the union line. It is an absolute disaster for small business. No wonder they want the tax package. Why don't you do the right thing and give it to them? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Can the minister confirm that the official unemployment rate for indigenous Australians stands at 23 per cent and that the real rate is generally understood to be considerably higher than that? Isn't it the case that the Howard government has consistently reduced coverage of the Community Development Employment Program through limiting the growth of existing schemes and the establishment of new programs? How can the government justify this reduction in specific employment programs for indigenous Australians, services which have both employment and community development aims for Aboriginals?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator McKiernan for the question because it is a very relevant question in relation to the Community Development Employment Program. The Community Development Employment Program was introduced by the Fraser government. It is one of the highlights of what has occurred in Aboriginal affairs over a long period of time. It was introduced to address the problem that occurs particularly in remote communities, where employment is a major problem. As Senator McKiernan has pointed out, there are particular problems in remote communities, where there are no other means of employment available, and the Community Development Employment Program allows the community to determine what action should be taken for the community itself rather than for the individuals. In the majority of cases it is part time.

answer.para: There have been claims recently that there have been deliberate attempts at reducing the number of CDEP places, and I am aware of the claims that Senator McKiernan referred to. I would refer senators to the Spicer report into the CDEP, which recommended a number of changes. They were accepted by both the government and ATSIC. Ian Spicer was formerly the executive officer for the—

talk.start.para: —ACCI.

—ACCI. Thank you, Senator Cook. In any case, Mr Spicer suggested that as many as one-third of CDEP recipients are not working but instead receiving what they call sit-down money. His view, which the government accepts, is that these people should be progressively shifted from CDEP to more appropriate social security programs. This means, if Mr Spicer's estimates are correct, that some 10,000 CDEP places will be freed up for use in new CDEPs or to expand existing ones. This issue needs to be addressed before additional CDEP places are funded. That was accepted by ATSIC as well, as Senator McKiernan may be interested to know.

answer.para: In regard to other recommendations by Mr Spicer, the government and ATSIC are enthusiastically pursuing them but they are being threatened by the Labor Party. In line with Mr Spicer's report, the government has sought to remove anomalies from the CDEP scheme. For example, CDEP recipients do not receive rental assistance, nor do they receive health cards or the $10 special allowance paid to mainstream Work for the Dole recipients. We have introduced legislation in the other place to correct these anomalies, to the benefit of the vast majority of CDEP recipients. So the vast majority of CDEP recipients will in fact have their position improved by these amendments. Labor, however—Senator McKiernan is reflecting this—was caught in its blind desire to oppose everything the government does and so voted against these changes. I would strongly urge senators opposite to reconsider their totally indefensible position when the legislation is debated in this place.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I thank the minister for his answer so far and I thank him for raising the Spicer report. Isn't it true, Minister, that Mr Spicer also said:

question.para: Across Australia CDEP has been critical in developing an improved sense of pride in community and culture, and has provided the basis for acquiring greater skills, employment and enterprise development resulting in ongoing social and economic growth.

Are these the aims of the government in considering issues of Aboriginal employment and, if so, will the government commit itself to maintaining and expanding the Community Development Employment Program?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator McKiernan for the congratulatory message in the supplementary question because there should be bipartisan support for those very aims. We are maintaining the CDEP programs. We are following the Spicer report, which was accepted, to the letter and we will encourage that the report be fulfilled. That is why I would ask the Labor Party to support the amendments that were brought in, in line with the supplementary question.

answer.para: The problem that exists—and I have put this to the government itself—is that with the burgeoning number of young Aboriginal people in the community, particularly in remote communities, action will need to be taken in the future to provide further CDEP places. So I can assure Senator McKiernan that that position is being addressed by the government.

subdebateinfo.title: Social Security Payments: Unemployment Benefit Recipients

talk.start.para: —I have a question for Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. The Howard government has a strong commitment to a fair and equitable social security system. Could the minister advise the Senate what the government is doing to ensure that people are meeting their obligations to the taxpayer and the community to be genuinely looking for work?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Eggleston for his question. The government recognises that the majority of people who are obtaining assistance under the social security legislation are both meeting their obligations to the taxpayer and genuinely looking for work. But unfortunately there is a small core of people who are not prepared to do either.

answer.para: We have had as a government, in the three years we have been in government, a very good track record in being determined to do what is needed, in terms of both legislation and also administration, to make sure that people are not able to defraud the system. We are honouring the public commitment we made to clean up the social security system. We are doing that because it is very important that the public have confidence in the social security system, because only then can those who are genuinely in need be assured that people will recognise that they are doing the right thing.

There is a story on the front page of the Courier-Mail this morning which refers to the government's continuing commitment to crack down on a small group of `hard-core' welfare rorters. The government is intending to legislate to further tighten the jobseeker provisions.

There are a couple of areas where we believe that people are setting out deliberately to cheat on the system. Currently people cannot continue to get the dole if they move from an area of high employment to an area of low employment. Unfortunately, some people have decided that they can circumvent that by taking themselves off unemployment benefits in the area of high employment and then immediately moving to an area of low employment and applying, so there is a break in their social security payments. In that way they have been able to avoid the legislation. People who try to circumvent the system like that are not deserving of the sympathy of those who are paying for the system.

talk.start.para: —What?
—People who try to deliberately circumvent the system—
—They are not defrauding anything.

—They are defrauding. The taxpayer is paying for people who are breaking the spirit of the legislation, and it is interesting to know that Senator Margetts is prepared to condone and support people who will go surfing on the taxpayer. Now, I don't mind people surfing in their own time but I think most Australians are not prepared to have people go surfing at their expense.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of intervention is too high.

—Madam President, for all the noise that is coming from the other side of the chamber about this, I would point out that the department retains discretion. Where somebody moves to an area of high unemployment for compassionate reasons—for example, to look after a sick parent—discretion can be exercised to allow the payment of the unemployment benefits to be made. But it is not on to simply subsidise people sunning themselves at taxpayers' expense.

answer.para: The second measure that the government will be legislating to deal with relates to people who apply for a job, thereby satisfying the activity test—a job that is some distance away from their place of residence, outside an area where they are compelled to look—and then turn down the job. Currently under the legislation they are able to do that. I do not think anybody who has been offered a job, who has been on unemployment benefits, should artificially use that as a means of satisfying the activity test in order to continue to receive unemployment benefits. The government will close that loophole as well. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Disabled People

talk.start.para: —My question is also directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Is the minister aware that submissions to the Senate GST community affairs references committee from individuals with disabilities and organisations representing people with disabilities have detailed time and again the very real concerns these people have as to the negative impact this tax reform package will have on them? Minister, given that a high proportion of these people will not be eligible for the much feted tax cuts, will at best receive a pension increase in real terms of a paltry $6.50 and will now be required to pay a GST on goods and particularly on services that were previously tax exempt and are vital to their existence, how can the government be sure that the modelling undertaken and compensation package offered to people with disabilities are adequate?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —It is of concern to all of us that people with disabilities be protected. But the government does believe, in formulating its draft legislation, that we have addressed the issues that need addressing to protect people with disabilities. We accepted the recommendations of the Voss committee's report and we made the vast bulk of disability services available GST free to the people who need them. Additionally, a comprehensive list of medical aids and appliances used by people with disabilities will also be GST free. If you are concerned about the commercial activities of charities and business services, they will be liable to GST.
—That was not the question.

—No, but I am giving you the information you obviously need, Senator, and I am happy to help you. The charities will be able to claim back any GST paid on all the inputs for these activities as an input tax credit. I do understand that sometimes the opposition does not want to be given the truth, but that is what they are getting.

answer.para: I think Senator Evans might be interested to know that the government's tax reforms are actually expected to reduce the cost of community services by about 2.7 per cent due to the abolition of 10 existing and inefficient taxes. That is not something which the government or members of parliament claim; it is something which has been determined on the advice of the Treasury.

talk.start.para: —No modelling.
—Of course that is modelling. What do you think, you goose? Madam President, there is a bit of yapping on the other side of the chamber.

answer.para: Turning to income support for people on disabilities, the Senate has been told over and over again—I think they must be tired of hearing it—that people on disability payments or any other kind of payment under the social security legislation or the veterans' affairs legislation will be receiving a four per cent increase in all the payments they receive. Before we hear the chorus from the other side of the chamber, let me say that not only is that four per cent up-front before there has been a single change in the cost of living for people, whether they are disabled or not, but also the commitment of the government is that that will be retained above the cost of living into the future so that people will always remain above the effect of the tax reforms.

Madam President, there is an awful lot of noise from across the way. Senators on the other side of the chamber are so determined to show that they are Neanderthals that they are not prepared to look at the assistance that is being given to community organisations to assist them to get ready—
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I don't know if I can shout over that noise much longer. Do you think that you could ask them to be quiet?
—Order! The level of noise is unacceptable.

—Thank you, Madam President. I was trying to point out to the opposition and to the Senate generally that there is a fund of $500 million which is available to small business and also to the charities and to those organisations providing disability services. That fund is there to help them in the implementation of tax reforms. In my consultations with the organisations, they appreciate that very much.

answer.para: The changes to the fringe benefits tax exemptions and the abolition of the wholesale sales tax, together with the removal of exemptions to sales tax, will streamline the funding arrangements for charities and public benevolent institutions, and make them more trans parent. The government is not in any way trying to harm them at all. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that my question was actually about the very real concerns of people with disabilities, and she failed to address those concerns at all. Isn't it true that the former Department of Social Security and the former Department of Health and Family Services had absolutely no input and gave absolutely no policy advice to the Treasury in respect of the effects a GST would have on people with disabilities? Isn't it true that the coalition have absolutely no idea how a GST will affect people with disabilities? Isn't it also true that the reason why the coalition government has not done any research in relation to the impact of a GST on people with disabilities is because you simply don't want to know the answers?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the question is no.

—My question is also to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. I ask the minister: is she prepared to listen to the 15 leading church and welfare groups who have, with one strong and united voice, today condemned the government's tax package as unfair, unjust and unacceptable? Will the minister and the government finally accept that the majority of Australians, supported by Australia's churches and welfare groups, do not trust the government to either deliver or maintain adequate compensation for a GST?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Lees for the question, but I point out to Senator Lees that the press release issued today by ACOSS, while it may have included more church and community groups in its announcement, is essentially based on the same analysis that ACOSS put out some time ago. I recognise that they have been desperately going around trying to find some analysis which will show tax reform in a less positive light than the submission that they made previously which indicated that every group would be better off—confirming what the government said. I know that they are now in a position where they are very keen to try to point to a failure by the government to see that people will be better off, but their own research that they commissioned, and that they released earlier, demonstrates that all those groups will be better off.

answer.para: Yesterday the Labor Party was indicating that they would not vote against excluding food from the tax reform. I think that is a very interesting development in that it is very important, from the point of view of a simple GST system—as you will have heard in the evidence given to you, Senator—that there be a very uncomplicated, simple system applied across the board. You would know that all the credible economists who have given evidence to the Senate committees have endorsed the fact that food should be included in the GST.

talk.start.para: —Who are they?
—Well, I will give you some names. Dixon, the Food Council, Professor Harding, and Professor Warren all made those claims about the inclusion of food in a simple system.
—What did Lawrence say about compensation?
—I am hearing Senator Lees talk about compensation—
—That was the other leader; that was Stott Despoja.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Was that Stott Despoja? I beg your pardon—Bib and Bub. I am sorry about that. Madam President, how can you tell whether it is Senator Stott Despoja or Senator Lees interjecting when the noise from across the way is so loud?
—Senator Newman, you should ignore interjections and apply yourself to the question.

—I understood that whoever was interjecting was seeking after wisdom, and it is desirable that the Democrats as well as the Labor Party seek after wisdom, because there is a great need for it. I do not know that there is a great deal to answer on the question of compensation that Senator Kemp has not answered over and over again.
—He hasn't answered it!

—Prior to that I have answered it. The Treasurer continues to answer it. The Prime Minister continues to answer it. We believe the compensation is fair and just. And ACOSS's own analysis has demonstrated that the groups will not be worse off.

—I am sorry, but I have to disagree with the minister. There is no such evidence before the committee, and I would suggest that she goes back and has a look. Madam President, I ask the minister: is she aware that the bottom 40 per cent of Australian households on average have incomes of less than $300 a week, and is she aware that the top 20 per cent of Australian households have on average incomes of over $1,500 a week? In the face of this evidence and the united opposition from churches and welfare, how can the minister justify the imposition of a 10 per cent GST on food on low and middle income Australia to fund $5 billion worth of tax cuts for the top 20 per cent of income earners?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Let me just answer Senator Lees in this way. I understand that if you remove the GST from food—and evidence has been given to this effect—you are benefiting the top bracket of wage earners to the extent of $5 and you are benefiting the bottom level of wage earners by $1. Is that fair? Is that what you are about?

—My question is to Senator Newman, Minister for Family and Community Services. Is the minister aware that last Thursday in the House Treasurer Costello described Professor Sijbren Cnossen, a judge of the Dutch tax court, as `one of the world's foremost indirect tax experts'? Is the minister also aware that the Treasurer told the House that it would be well advised to take notice of Professor Cnossen's view on the GST? Can the minister confirm that Professor Cnossen has criticised the government's tax package, particularly on the basis that it undercompensates the poor through assuming a uniform household spending pattern? If the man recognised by Treasurer Costello as one of the world's foremost experts on indirect tax believes the compensation package is inadequate and inaccurate, why should it have any credibility with the Australian community, including low income earners?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The professor acknowledged that the compensation package in the government's tax plan is more than sufficient, though you would not know that from the opposition's question. He also gave his firm support for retaining a GST on food. However, he argued for a compensation model based on different household spending types. The government has not tried to do this for what we believe are very good reasons. Small differences in the CPI effects across household types simply cannot be reliably measured, according to the advice I have—
—Oh, you don't know.
—Madam President—
—Order! There is an appropriate time to ask follow up questions and it is not now.

—The advice I have from my department is that small differences in the CPI effects across household types simply cannot be reliably measured and are therefore not an appropriate basis for designing compensation packages.
—What about Fightback? This is not what you did in Fightback.

—Madam President, they do hate the truth, don't they? It is also far better to build compensation around the total CPI effect across all household types. In any case, we have put sufficient extra compensation in to ensure that low income earners are fully compensated, even if the worst case numbers in the household expenditure survey were accepted. And I expect that the study referred to by the professor will find this.

answer.para: Boosting direct payments and delivering income tax cuts was the easiest way to provide compensation. In the case of family payments, in respect of which the Treasurer announced today that legislation is now coming into the parliament, the changes will also greatly simplify and improve people's choices, and make a great deal of difference to the choice of life for families. The alternative approach put by the professor—refundable tax rebates—could be made to deliver similar cash outcomes but it would be much more complex and it would limit choice. For that reason, the government did not go down that route.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. How can you say, Minister, that low income earners are fully compensated when your party's expert—the Treasurer's expert, Professor Cnossen—says that the package undercompensates the poor through assuming uniform household spending patterns? Are you aware that Professor Cnossen is a former adviser to the International Monetary Fund and has assisted 25 governments in the design and implementation of their GSTs? Again, Minister, if this acknowledged expert believes the compensation package is inadequate and inaccurate, why should it have any credibility in the Australian community?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I do not think Senator Cook heard more than what he wanted to hear out of my answer. I am very happy to repeat for him that Professor Cnossen acknowledged that the compensation package in the government's tax plan is more than sufficient. Senator, I think you just did not listen. That is the answer to your supplementary.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I refer to the recent announcement of an inquiry into the Collins submarine project by an independent panel headed by Mr John Prescott, former CEO of BHP, and Dr Malcolm McIntosh, and I ask: was the government aware when making these appointments that BHP has done large amounts of business with the submarine project, including the supply of the CMAC system which was criticised by the Australian National Audit Office in its 1992 report? Was the government also aware that in 1987, when the submarine contract was under consideration, Dr McIntosh was First Assistant Secretary, Defence Industry and Materiel Policy in the Department of Defence, in which capacity he would have been involved in deliberations leading to the choice of ASC as contractor? Does the minister agree that the choice of these men for a so-called `independent' investigation compromises the investigation before it begins? If not, why not?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence will have his reasons as to the people he has chosen. In fact, in both cases, I believe them to be people of eminent qualification. I point out that, as far as Dr McIntosh is concerned, his experience is a great deal wider than that which you chose to quote, Senator. He headed defence procurement for the British Defence Force for a number of years. When I spoke to defence leaders in Britain some years ago, they were very loath to lose him because of his capabilities. He is now, of course, the head of CSIRO. I would have thought that that sort of expertise was invaluable in this sort of exercise.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. We were not talking about expertise, we were talking about conflict of interest. I remind the minister that my question goes to the issue of possible or perceived conflict of interest for Messrs McIntosh and Prescott, both of whom have long track records with organisations closely connected with the submarine project. Does the minister not agree that, in supposedly independent inquiries such as this, the perception of conflict of interest is as important as it is in judicial circles?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I think the conflict of interest in this case is in the eye of the beholder. I would suggest that you would have to go a very long way in Australia to get the sort of expertise that you will need to make an intelligent inquiry. There can be nothing worse—

answer.para: Senator Margetts interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator, hear me out. There can be nothing worse than having somebody who knows nothing about these matters at all inquiring into issues which are of very serious import. The arrangements for the submarine over the years are complex and technical, and it is very important that they be sorted out. The government could have had the choice of doing an internal inquiry. I presume you would not have thought that was the appropriate way to go. This is quite clearly an arms-length inquiry and I believe that it is an appropriate use of people with great technical and managerial abilities.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Minister, in the interests of maintaining a strong and independent national broadcaster, will you rule out any possibility of Mr Max Moore-Wilton being appointed as Managing Director of the ABC?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not sure what underlies that question. —I address my question to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. The coalition government was re-elected with a clear mandate to replace Labor's outdated and unfair tax regime with a new system that will boost Australia into the next millennium. Will the minister explain how tax reform will benefit indigenous Australians, particularly those living in remote and isolated areas?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Boswell for this very important question. Low income people living in remote areas, whether indigenous or not, will gain a great deal from the government's tax reform package. The tax package will be of considerable benefit to indigenous Australians.

answer.para: Senator Cook interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Cook may be interested to know that, when the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's own research on the impact of the reform package is analysed, it is very favourable. While ATSIC's submission to the tax reform Senate inquiries raises a lot of rhetorical questions, the ATSIC figures by Allen Consulting actually support the government's position. For example, Senator Cook may be interested to know that ATSIC's figures show that, in a worst case scenario, there would be an inflation increase of 3.74 per cent. This is below the four per cent compensation package the government will put in place. The ATSIC figures do not take into account the benefits of lower transport costs by reduced diesel fuel prices.

answer.para: In developing the tax package, we have been very careful to ensure that geographically isolated people get as much benefit from tax reform as people in cities and towns. In specific terms, increases in social security payments and income tax cuts are part of a raft of important compensation measures. These measures will ensure that indigenous people on low incomes, income support and CDEP—as Senator McKiernan mentioned—are not only compensated for the impact of the GST but also share in the gains of the new system.

It also has to be remembered that the indigenous median age is about half that of the wider community. Senator Cook may be interested to know that, as a result, indigenous families are larger and younger. So they will also receive substantial benefits from increased family allowance payments. We have allowed sufficient margin for people not to be disadvantaged in remote areas, where costs can be higher. Social security payments will be increased by four per cent to cover an estimated cost of living increase of around 1.9 per cent. Income support benefits will be kept 1.5 per cent higher than they would have been had the normal indexation arrangements been applied. While some food items might increase, many in fact will be cheaper because we will abolish Labor's hidden tax—the wholesale sales tax—which taxed people at up to 30 per cent. That included people in rural and remote areas.

A reduction of diesel fuel excise will significantly cut transport costs for heavy vehicles, by up to 19c a litre, resulting in an overall balance in the cost of living. Road transport organisations have already indicated that transport cost savings will be passed on to consumers, particularly those in rural and remote areas. We will see benefits flowing on to consumers at the supermarket shelf and the petrol bowser.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are senators on my left interjecting persistently.

—Businesses in remote areas can expect, on average, a 3.2 per cent reduction in operating costs, as well as looking forward to other avenues of non-tax related support that the government is planning to introduce over the next 12 months.
—There is no evidence for that at all.
—If Senator Cook and the opposition parties are serious about helping Australia and its peoples, particularly those in rural and remote areas, they will support the government's tax reform package.

—I address my question to Senator Hill as Minister for the Environment and Heritage. Can the minister confirm that drilling associated with the Jabiluka mine will be conducted in the next few weeks within the area of the Boyweg-Almudj sacred sites? Can he also confirm that these are the sites which were recently considered by the World Heritage Committee of UNESCO to be integral to the Kakadu cultural landscape and therefore of unique value to the world? What action does the minister intend to take to protect these sacred sites?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Senator Bolkus would be aware of the expanding definition of the Boyweg sacred site in the Jabiluka area. It is difficult to reconcile recent claims with the history of research in the area, the facts relating to legally binding permissions given for works on the lease, and the actions of traditional owners over the last 20 years. From 1975 on, the site of Boyweg has been known, photographed, mapped and protected. Several reputable anthropologists, working closely with traditional owners, including the father of the current senior traditional owner, have defined the site of Boyweg as a `small discrete soakage or spring on the edge of the wetlands located to the west of the Jabiluka mine valley'. It was regarded as a sacred but not a dangerous site.

answer.para: This site is linked by a dreaming trail to another separate site known as Almudj, also protected and registered. The area between these sites is claimed now by some to be a sacred site. The location and definition of the site was discussed and confirmed in the 1977 Fox inquiry, the claim book for the 1982 Alligator Rivers stage 2 land claim, and the research necessary for registration on the National Estate for sites on the lease, including Boyweg and Almudj. Furthermore, between 1971 and 1978, before the area became Aboriginal land, Pancontinental drilled some 250 holes in the mine valley in the area between the two sites.

In 1980, Justice Toohey heard evidence in the Alligator Rivers stage 2 land claim. Evidence was provided by the current traditional owner's father who described Boyweg as: `Just up here where the buffalo wallow is now. It used to be a sacred site before.' In 1981, Justice Toohey reported his findings on the land claim. While his report gives considerable attention to the proposed Jabiluka project—as it was, of course, then planned—no concerns over Boyweg or Almudj were noted. Although the proposal was much larger than the present initiative, the site does not appear to have been under any threat.

In the years leading up to 1982, the Northern Land Council carried out extensive consultation with traditional owners and affected Aboriginal communities over the Jabiluka project. In 1982, an agreement was signed which stated:

It was agreed by the NLC on behalf of traditional Aboriginal owners that there are no sacred sites within the fenced area. Traditional Aboriginal owners have instructed the NLC that they have no present intention of conferring upon any place the status of a sacred site within the fenced area during the term of the deed.

That is, in 1982 the traditional owners were saying that there was no sacred site. The current area now claimed to be Boyweg includes part of that fenced area to which I just referred. It was not until 1997, some 15 years later, that claims started to be made about an extended area for Boyweg, possibly covering the whole of the mine valley. These revisions also upgraded the category of the site from sacred to sacred and dangerous.

In 1997, the Aboriginal Areas Protection Authority, including 10 out of 12 Aboriginal site custodians, declined to register the site citing disagreement among traditional owners over its location and significance. It was not until 1999 that traditional owners informed me that they now believe that this site was wider, covering the whole mine valley, and more significant, et cetera. Therefore, the sign is one of evolutionary growth, Senator Bolkus. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister contend, despite the assessment of the International World Heritage Committee, despite a deed of trust between the company—ERA—and the traditional owners, that there is no sacred site there? Why will the minister take no action at all to protect sacred sites recognised by the World Heritage Committee? Why is the minister now expounding an argument that he has not expounded before bringing into dispute the actual existence of the sacred site? Minister, what action will you take to meet your responsibilities as Minister for the Environment and Heritage responsible for Australia's world heritage properties to protect the values of these sites?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Madam President, Senator Bolkus was not listening. What I said to him was that by 1999 the site had suddenly been expanded to include the whole of the valley. It increased in significance to involve more dreaming ancestors and to become a dangerous site and, of course, for the first time it had become an underground site as well as an on-ground site. The trouble with the new expanded claims is that they are not consistent with the known facts. They are out of step with the agreement signed by the traditional owners, supported by the NLC, and they have not been accepted by the Aboriginal Areas Protection Authority.

Senator HILL

Senator NEWMAN

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. The Howard government has a strong commitment to provide education opportunities for all Australians so that they can reach their full potential. I refer the minister to children of itinerant families who have great difficulty in attending distance education or boarding schools due to the occupation of their parents and I refer in particular, as you would know, Minister, to the children of travelling show workers. Would you advise the Senate of the efforts the Howard government has made to improve educational outcomes for the children of such itinerant workers?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —Showmen and show-women in travelling shows throughout this country have made a very colourful contribution to Australia's history. A contribution has also been made by the families of those showmen and show-women and for many years the children of those families have been overlooked. That was until now. The Commonwealth has announced $1.42 million in capital funding for a school for the children of members of the Showmen's Guild.

answer.para: I acknowledge the work that Senator Calvert has done in relation to this. Senator Calvert lobbied me last year when I was minister for schools and he continued that good work with Dr Kemp, the minister for education. I want to congratulate Dr Kemp, the minister for education, for recognising the plight of these children which had gone unnoticed previously.

The Commonwealth will meet the capital costs of establishing a school for the children of travelling show workers. The Queensland government will run the school through Education Queensland. The school will operate in two parts, with each part accompanying a show troupe as it moves across the eastern part of Australia. Two circuits will make that journey on the eastern seaboard. Each part of the school will be staffed by two teachers, a teachers' aide and a school principal will coordinate the school's activities. It is expected the school will commence operations later this year.

The children of families who lead an itinerant lifestyle, such as show workers, cannot use the normal educational services that the rest of the community takes for granted. It is no secret that the children of these people are disadvantaged in an educational sense. The choice they have is either to stay at home and not see their parents or to join them on the road. We now have an answer to that. Although there are some 80 children involved, it is still a very important move because we are now setting an example not only for other areas where mobile schools might be used but also on the international scene where there has been some international interest in this. Senator Calvert brought to my attention the fact that there have been similar exercises in Europe.

This initiative underlines the government's strong commitment to those children in regional areas who suffer educational disadvantage. In fact, we have announced $22 million in funding for isolated children to boost the funding in place of $150 million over five years which will start this year. Although this is just part of our program for educating children in regional areas, it is nonetheless a very important part. I look forward to the success of the school for the children of travelling show workers and, once again, I acknowledge the efforts of Senator Calvert in pushing this issue.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Disabled People

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Family and Community Services (Senator Newman), to questions without notice asked today, relating to the proposed new tax system.

I particularly want to concentrate on the answer Senator Newman gave to my question about the concerns of people with disabilities regarding the impact of the GST on their standard of living, their quality of life and the barriers that the GST will erect to their full participation in the community. It was very clear from the minister's answer today that the government has done no modelling and conducted no impact studies on the effect of the GST on the lives of people with disabilities and the organisations that support them.

It was very clear from answers to questions during the committee inquiry process that the Department of Health and Aged Care and the Department of Family and Community Services have done no work to try to influence Treasury's modelling and Treasury's compensation packages for people with disabilities. This means that the government has no idea of the impact of its GST tax package on people with disabilities. We think this is deplorable. We think the government stands condemned for failing to do the work, for failing to take enough interest to work out what the impact will be and to work out whether or not the compensation packages offered in conjunction with the tax package will be sufficient to assist those people through the changed taxation regime.

It is just not good enough for the government to say they do not know. They have an obligation to care, they have an obligation to do the work to ensure that the tax package is fair for those persons. What is clear today from the press release from the Joint Church and Community Services Alliance Group is that they reject the government's often asserted claim that the tax package is fair. It clearly is not fair, and one of the key groups disadvantaged by the tax package is people with disabilities, but of course that also includes pensioners and a whole range of other people on fixed incomes who will be severely disadvantaged by the totality of the tax package.

It is clear that the government have taken the attitude that we will throw everyone into a pot, work out the average and the average will do for all: the average compensation package, the average outcome in terms of housing, the average outcome in terms of cost of living. People are not averages. People do not eat averages. People's lives are different, their experiences are different and their needs are different. One of the key groups that is very different in terms of their needs is people with disabilities, because they have very different needs from others in the community.

One of the things that is clear about people with disabilities is that they have a very different consumption pattern. They are large consumers of services and they need extra services. They need assistance with personal services—and most of those look like they will be GST free. But there is a range of other services which they consume in greater quantities than other people do—things like transportation, home help services, handyman services, home maintenance. All those things that we are able to do ourselves, very often people with disabilities have to employ someone to do. They use services that are largely discretionary for other people.

In introducing a goods and services tax, the government are introducing a tax on services, in most cases, for the first time. People who use a lot of services have a disproportionate impact placed upon them by the imposition of this tax. The services part of the new taxation regime will seriously impact on the quality of life of people with disabilities. In general, these people are doing it tough already—surviving on low incomes and having to overcome huge barriers to their full participation in the community. And we are adding another 10 per cent barrier to their participation in the community, their enjoyment of life and their ability to participate in the things that other people take for granted.

The services that people with disabilities use are widespread and costly, and they spend a disproportionate amount of their income already on services. By taxing services, we increase the cost of that consumption and we increase their inability to fully participate in the community, because the costs of the services they need are increased.

The government have done nothing to appreciate that. They have done nothing to examine the impacts of the GST on the lives of people with disabilities. All the groups have been before the GST Community Affairs Committee making this very case. They have provided the detailed information on consumption patterns, and the government say, `You will all be better off because, on average, it will all be okay.' But, with every average, there has to be someone above the average and someone below the average. And the people below the average are the people with disabilities—the people who will have to consume large amounts of services. They are going to be taxed a disproportionate amount, and there will be a much more adverse effect on their lifestyles as a result of the government's taxation package.

The government must do some modelling. The government must address the issues of people with disabilities and ensure that they have a much better result from this tax package than they currently look like getting if the government is successful in having this legislation passed.

talk.start.para: —Again we are hearing the opposition trying to justify why they will not support the taxation reform—something they realised has been needed since 1985. Because they did not have the gall or the guts to do it, they left it languishing and they left us with a ramshackle wholesale sales tax system with a labyrinth of taxes on food, personal items and many other goods. I find it amazing that members on the other side can come into this chamber and go on and on peddling myths. Senator Evans just said that people with disabilities will be paying 10 per cent more on every item. That is absolutely outrageous.
—How can you say that?

—I can say it because none of those on the other side understand the system that they currently support. They have no policies—not a policy between them. There are a couple of ways: third ways, fourth ways, fifth ways, halfways—with Latham and some of the—
—Pathways.
—Oh, pathways.
—Why don't you say something of substance?

—Senator Lundy never says anything of substance in this chamber. What we have is a party on the other side with no policies. The only policies they have is that they support a wholesale sales tax system which is ramshackle. It is a system which has tax on some items of food and most of the things you see in the supermarket: dog food, gladwrap, birthday cards—all those sorts of things. When Labor put up the wholesale sales tax, by an enormous amount, was there one penny of compensation? No.

speech.para: Gary Johns, a former minister in the Labor Party, tells us what they did. During the 1993 election, they promised that they would not raise taxes and that they would reduce income taxes. They promised l-a-w tax cuts. They raised wholesale sales taxes, they delivered only half the income taxes and they gave no compensation to people on pensions and no compensation to any individual whom they are pretending to represent. What absolute hypocrisy!

Gary Johns said that they should realise what they should be doing and support taxation reform, because that was what was identified by Paul Keating in 1985. He said there are three main advantages of a consumption tax: it would allow a more rational indirect tax system than the wholesale sales tax system, it would allow greater tax revenues to be generated for the benefit of individuals and tax rate reduction, and it would generate tax from those who evade or avoid income tax. It would provide a useful net dividend for distribution to the rest of the community.

The other thing they forget to remind people about is that we have a tax system, the base of which is becoming narrower and narrower. In fact, what we have not got is a party on the other side with a vision for the future, that asks, `How are we going to support health? How are we going to support social security? How are we going to support benefits for people with a disability into the future?' Under current Labor Party policy—I can only presume that their policy is to support wholesale sales tax and increases in wholesale sales tax—

talk.start.para: —That was their past.

—That was their past, as Senator Hill said. They have no pathway for the future so they have no plans for how they are going to provide pensions, support for people with disabilities and health care into the future. As our dependence on goods narrows and our economy depends more and more on services, our tax base is narrowing. They have no plans at all for the future.
—This whole program means no extra revenue.

—Senator Crowley keeps shouting across the chamber. You have nothing to say. You are going to have a chance to get up and respond but you have no policies and nothing to offer. Let me say to you that the Australian public—

speech.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Gibbs, Senator Hill and Senator Crowley. I want some order in this chamber, please.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. It was a bit of a challenge. I was trying awfully hard to talk over the top of those people on the other side, who are supporting a system which is totally insupportable. No wonder they need to shout across the chamber.

speech.para: Senator Hill interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Hill!
—Order! Senator Gibbs, you are not helping either. If the three of you were to remain silent, Senator Patterson might have some chance.
—Senator Eggleston, you will get a go later on.

—Taxation reform is not just about a GST, it is about righting the mistakes of the previous government and providing a fair and more equitable system. That is what we are about—a system which is sustainable into the future, which is something that you know nothing about. (Time expired)

—We have here today answers from a minister that show very clearly that this government, at best, does not know what its new tax package is about, does not know the impact of the GST, because it has done no modelling except in Treasury. Senator Newman's department has done no modelling. The health department has done no modelling, and it could answer no questions when we asked it in our committee, `What will be the impact?' But many of the witnesses who came before our committee knew the impact.

speech.para: Many of those are back today as an alliance of the Australian Council of Social Service, the Uniting Church, the Brotherhood of St Laurence, the Women's Electoral Lobby, the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, the Australian Consumers Association, the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, Anglicare, the Catholic Social Welfare Commission, St Vincent de Paul and some elements of the Salvation Army. No way are these paid up stoolies for the Labor Party, and no way are they are a bunch of ratbags. They brought excellent evidence before our committee, and they have brought it back again today. They say what is clear to anybody who is serious about looking at this bill—that this tax package is very unfair, and it will entrench inequality in Australia well into the future if it should pass. It will divide Australia into the haves and the have-nots. It is based on a trickle-up effect, where the poor pay the tax and the rich take it home. It is quite outrageous.

The government over there pretend that they know it is about something else. Those people whose names I have listed have all done the serious work. They got groups of reliable, responsible accountants like Ernst and Young and Arthur Andersen to do the work for them—to make sure that they have not got it wrong—and they are clear: low income families in Australia will have grossly inadequate compensation.

It is very interesting that, at the very time that legislation was introduced that will divide Australia into the haves and the have-nots, the Prime Minister went before large sections of corporate Australia last weekend to say, `I've got $50 million of precious taxpayer money, and I'm going to set that aside as tax deductions for corporate Australia to encourage them to become philanthropists.' For the first time ever, he is taxing the charitable institutions in this country—if he has $50 million to spare, why doesn't he give it to the charities that do the work on the ground, instead of giving tax cuts to corporate Australia in case they are generous?

It is a very big irony that the Prime Minister should be encouraging philanthropy with massive tax cuts when at the same time he is introducing for the first time ever taxes on the charitable and not-for-profit sector in this country. It is completely against the fabric of Australian society to tax charitable and not-for-profit institutions. How about this: for the first time ever, a tax on the Girl Guides and a tax on the Boy Scouts. We have seen how the government says, `Well, we didn't mean it on bob-a-job.' What about bob-a-job week? What about the Girl Guide biscuits? What about the surf lifesavers and St Vincent de Paul? What about the GST on the lamington cake stall? That is what this government is introducing.
Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You may bay, but it was those institutions that brought this evidence before us—not the Labor Party. For the first time ever, you are taxing the charitable and not-for-profit sector, and at the same time your Prime Minister has found $50 million, which he is setting aside for institutions in this country should they get into further philanthropy. It is an extraordinary piece of legislation. It takes no regard of the sort of Australia that we have become—a society where people want to put in their pennyworth and contribute through voluntary activity and through charitable and not-for-profit institutions. Now that is under attack.

speech.para: More importantly than anything, it is an unfair, ungenerous bill that is going to make the poor and the low income families poorer and worse off than ever before. Under law, that poverty and that lack of income will be there forever. We all know that any compensation, small as it is, will not last. In every other country the GST has risen. It will rise in this country because there is no extra revenue out of these bills. It is just a different way of making the money go round. What is happening is the poor are paying for the rich. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I must say that Senator Crowley made a lot of very strong assertions there which have absolutely no basis in fact whatsoever. She said, for example, that the minister did not understand what the government's tax package was about. It is absolute nonsense to think that the Minister for Family and Community Services would not understand how the tax package impacts on the 1.5 million Australians who have some disability and need personal care and assistance. Of course the minister understands that. Senator Crowley's assertion that the government did no modelling to work out what the impact on people with disabilities would be is absolute nonsense, as was her first assertion that the minister did not understand what the package had for people with disabilities and what compensation it provided.

speech.para: In formulating its draft goods and services tax legislation, the government accepted the recommendations of the Vos committee report and made the vast bulk of disability services available GST free to people who need them. Additionally, because we are a caring and sensitive government that makes sure that people with disabilities are not in any way unfairly dealt with, the government has made available a comprehensive list of medical aids and appliances used by people with disabilities which are to be GST free. So, in following the recommendations of the Vos report, the government has made sure that the services available to people with disabilities and the mechanical and other aids they need are GST free.

It is true that the commercial activities of charities and business services run by organisations involved with disabled people will attract a GST. However, just as with any other organisation or business, they will be able to claim back the GST paid on all inputs and will receive an input tax credit.

talk.start.para: —What about the services?

—Furthermore, the government's tax reforms are expected to reduce the cost of community services by 2.7 per cent due to the abolition of 10 existing and inefficient taxes. Those taxes pervade the whole work environment. So the answer to `What about the services?' is that the services will be cheaper and that people with disabilities who are on disability service pensions will be compensated by the four per cent increase in pensions and by the other compensation means available through the tax package. An essential theme of this tax package is that people with disabilities should not be disadvantaged at all. For that reason, the government has gone out of its way to make sure that, as I have said, the services and mechanical aids required by people with disabilities are GST free.

speech.para: Senator Crowley mentioned a long list of people and organisations who made submissions to the committee. I attended hearings of this committee, along with Senator Crowley and a number of other members of the Senate, and I must say that my impression was that many of the people who made submissions displayed a great lack of knowledge and understanding of the tax package. This was in spite of the fact that the government distributed a comprehensive community sector briefing kit which covered most of the issues raised. All this goes to show that, like the opposition and like many other organisations who appeared before the various GST committees, the bill had not been read, that the proposals had not been understood and that most of the evidence given and the complaints made were in ignorance of how the proposed tax package will work and, in particular in terms of disabled people, in ignorance of the fact that the government has gone out of its way to ensure that the disabled of Australia are not disadvantaged and are adequately compensated by this package.

talk.start.para: —I have never heard such waffle in all my life. First of all, we had Senator Patterson slagging off, talking about anything and everything apart from people with disabilities.

speech.para: Senator Patterson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Yes, you were, Senator Patterson—slagging off, just like you always do; you talk about anything apart from the subject.
—Order! Senator Gibbs, would you address the chair and, Senator Patterson, cease interjecting, thank you.

—We then had Senator Eggleston defending the minister and saying that of course the minister knows about this legislation and of course the minister knows about modelling. But Senator Eggleston was actually on this inquiry with us, and he was there when the department of social security and the department of health gave evidence that they were not consulted by Treasury or by the minister, that they had absolutely no input into what would happen with people with disabilities, with aged care or with people in need of health services.

speech.para: Senator Eggleston interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You were actually there, Senator Eggleston.
—Please address the chair, Senator Gibbs.

—Madam Deputy President, time and time again the witnesses before the Community Affairs GST inquiry stressed that the four per cent compensation was not adequate, that it was not going to be enough to cover the costs that would impact with the introduction of the GST.

speech.para: People with disabilities suffer higher unemployment rates and have lower incomes than people in the community generally. Their cost of living is much higher due to the specialised living expenses they have, including housing, transport, medical, pharmaceuticals, disability equipment, personal care and miscellaneous costs. Transportation in particular is vital to people with disabilities. We were given evidence that taxis are commonly used because people with a disability are often unable to access public transport or drive a car and so have no other option. A normal person can get into their car or can catch a bus, train or plane. Whatever they want to do, they have that choice. But these people do not have an option.

They do not have an option with the services they have to have in their homes. If people choose to live independently, they have maintenance costs—the lawnmower man has to come, they need house maintenance and cleaning and gardening services and the car has to be washed. These people must even employ someone to fit a light bulb—something which is nothing to us. This is a service and the GST applies to services. They do not have a choice; their expenses are enormous. They have special needs in areas that we take for granted.
Let me quote something:

The Physical Disability Council of NSW submitted an analysis of the effect of the GST on people with a disability. The council contended that the CPI effect on people with disabilities will be greater than the 1.9—2.2 per cent Treasury calculations and could be as high as 2.4—2.7 per cent.

talk.start.para: —They will get four per cent.

—Four per cent is not going to cover it, Senator—absolutely not. To show the inequity of this tax, a single person on $75,000 will receive a benefit of $68.55 per week. This is equivalent to 38 per cent of the total disability support pension, which will increase by merely $2.54 a week. It is not enough to cover their expenses. They are going to pay GST on services that have no tax now; you are going to put a GST on these people. Do you know what you are going to do? Do you care what you are doing to these people?
—No, they do not care.
—No, you do not care. Have you any idea how these people have to live?
—Tell the truth.
—I am telling the truth. (Time expired)

—What is really extraordinary in this debate is the fact that, if there were any compelling evidence at all that the compensation package is inadequate, the government could address it. But we have had four months of a travelling roadshow—the inquiry into the GST—which has turned out an absolute mishmash of criticisms without very much foundation at all. That is the problem—look at today's report of the litany of organisations that joined in the criticism that ACOSS made of the GST. As Senator Newman said, ACOSS's criticisms do not seem to have changed much since the very beginning. You have to understand that ACOSS was never, ever going to support the model because it shifts tax from a direct to an indirect base and that is just something that ACOSS will not support.

speech.para: By the same token, and this must be said, ACOSS supports tax reform because it realises—I would suggest it is an absolutely self-evident proposition—that unless there is fundamental tax reform there is a serious problem for the social security base—it is put totally at risk. It is self-evident that ACOSS does support tax reform; it might not like the model, but it was never going to like it. If you accept these fundamental assumptions then you can put the criticisms in context.

It is very easy to criticise the GST package and to not really expose your own conclusions. Although I have not been on the GST committees, I suspect that that is very much what has happened over these past four months. There has been a barrage of criticism with very little foundation and very little to support conclusions.

I find quite offensive the suggestion made this afternoon that the government is unsympathetic to people who are adversely impacted by the GST, by any reform package or by any policy position. The fact that there is a generous compensation package clearly underscores the fact that the government is concerned about people on low incomes, people with disabilities and certainly the elderly. Proof of that is not only in the compensation package but also in the fact that, in the formulation of the draft GST legislation, the government has accepted recommendations of the Vos committee's report and made the vast bulk of disability services available GST free to people who need them. That does not seem to me to be a government that is not concerned about how a package will impact on people with disabilities.

A comprehensive number of medical aids and appliances used by people with disabilities will also be GST free. As Senator Newman pointed out, commercial activities and business services of charities will be liable for a GST because they are just that—they are commercial activities—but they will be able to claim back, as indeed any other business can, any GST paid on inputs for these activities as an input tax credit. No convincing case has been made as to why there should be any different treatment for commercial activities.

The government's tax reforms are expected to reduce the cost of community services by about 2.7 per cent due to the abolition of 10 existing and inefficient taxes which pervade the whole system and which, I strongly suggest, impact much more strongly and much more unfairly on people with disabilities. They are hidden taxes that everyone in the community has to deal with.

Pensions for people with disabilities will rise by four per cent to assist with the impact of tax reforms. There has not yet been one convincing bit of modelling or evidence before any GST committee, so far as I know, that proves that that is inadequate. If somebody can come forward with convincing evidence, then you would be talking to a government that would be prepared to listen, but so far no-one has come forward. (Time expired)
