debateinfo.title: SOCIAL SECURITY (MEANING OF SEASONAL WORK) DETERMINATION

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Social Security (Meaning of Seasonal Work) Determination 1998, made under subsection 16A(2) of the Social Security Act 1991 , be disallowed.

The Social Security (Meaning of Seasonal Work) Determination defines intermittent work as work that is to be regarded as seasonal work for the purposes of the seasonal work waiting period provisions in the Social Security Act. The seasonal work waiting period was introduced by the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Act 1997, and applies to seasonal workers applying for Newstart allowance, youth allowance, mature age allowance, parenting payment for married people and partner allowance who have been engaged in such work in the six months prior to claiming one of these payments and who have earned above average weekly ordinary time earnings from that work—currently $736.70 gross per week.

The act defines seasonal work as (a) work that, because of its nature or factors peculiar to the industry in which it is performed, is available at approximately the same time or times every year for part or parts only of the year, or (b) work that is intermittent and is determined by disallowable instrument to be seasonal work.

Under the government's original proposal, the length of the period was calculated by determining how much in excess of average earnings the person made while engaged in seasonal work and dividing the excess by the average earnings figure to arrive at a period of weeks. This ignored the fact that some seasonal workers work for intermittent periods and support themselves during intervening periods before claiming a social security payment. It also failed to take account of the fact that some seasonal workers such as shearers who travel from job to job have unusually high employment-related expenses.

The government agreed to amend the provisions to deal with these issues, and we supported the measures as amended. I understand that the original provisions were aimed at seasonal workers and certain industries where people can earn very substantial amounts of money in short periods each year and claim benefits for much of the remainder of the year. In some cases, seasonal workers can earn considerably more than average yearly earnings in well under 12 months and can then apply for Newstart allowance; and they can do this year in, year out. Of course, they may be subject to other waiting periods under the Social Security Act, but they could still receive benefits for substantial parts of the year if it were not for the seasonal work waiting period.

Despite the baseless accusations made recently by the government, Labor is not about allowing people to take advantage of the system in this way. That is why we supported the original measures once the government had agreed with our proposed amendments concerning workers who support themselves between periods of work and workers who have high employment costs. What we are opposing is the government's extension of the seasonal work waiting period to casual and contract workers in virtually every industry, regardless of their average yearly earnings or whether they have any job security. It is an important matter because of the increase in contract and occasional work and the number of people who operate on that basis. That is the effect of this instrument.

talk.start.para: —That is not true.
—Senator Newman, you will get your go to reply.
—I just cannot believe you would say that.

—As I say, Senator Newman, you will get your turn. That is the effect of this instrument. It applies to: (a) managers and administrators, (b) professionals, (c) associate professionals, (d) tradespersons and related workers, (e) clerical, sales and service workers, (f) production and transport workers, and (g) labourers and related workers, provided that they are engaged to do a specific project or task, or for a set period, or to do work that is affected by regular shutdowns and they do not accrue leave entitlements and the work in question has lasted less than 12 months.

speech.para: This appears to represent a substantial departure from the original rationale for the rule. It is no longer aimed at workers who are routinely engaged in extremely lucrative employment for the same short period every year. Some casual workers who would come within the definition contained in the disallowable instrument might wait for many months before securing a relatively short period of highly paid work. These workers may struggle through months of poverty over the year and have no idea if or when they might find such work again.

Casual teachers are an example. I understand there are something in the order of 20,000 casual teachers in New South Wales alone. New teachers may have to wait up to three or four years before finding a permanent position and face very uncertain employment prospects in the interim. In some areas there is a shortage of casual teaching positions and work is hard to come by. Some of these teachers have significant teaching experience and can make well over average earnings when they are lucky enough to find work. But their income over the whole year may be well below the average wage.

As with other waiting periods, the seasonal work waiting period is subject to hardship provisions, but the conditions under which the waiting period can be waived are stringent. Before waiver can be considered, the person must be in severe financial hardship due to unavoidable or reasonable expenditure. A single person will not be regarded as being in severe financial hardship unless their liquid assets are less than the equivalent of two weeks of the allowance they are applying for, plus rent assistance and pharmaceutical allowance if they qualify for these amounts. This can be as little as $323.40 for a single Newstart Allowance claimant. It effectively means that the waiting period will not be waived if the person has managed to save a reasonable amount to help them through the next period of unemployment, which may well be lengthy. Clearly, people in this position will try to do that. That would be the only prudent thing for them to do.

The effect of the seasonal work waiting period on casual workers may be much harsher than the rules applying to permanent employees who lose their employment. For example, the income maintenance period for a person who has lost their permanent employment will be equal to the number of weeks of leave they are entitled to. If they took their leave as they became entitled to it, they would probably have to wait no more than four weeks to become entitled to a social security benefit, regardless of how long they had been working or how much they had earned. If that person had savings of $2,500 or less at the time they became unemployed, they would not be affected by the liquid assets test.

By contrast, a casual worker who had been unemployed for eight months before obtaining casual work for four months at 1½ times the average weekly earnings could be subject to a waiting period of two months. Reduction of the waiting period on the basis of hardship could not even be considered while they have savings in excess of $323. In short, this measure will often single out casual workers and treat them more harshly than those with a permanent job, who might well have had that job for a long period of time. This may be fair enough in cases where workers earn above average yearly earnings over short periods each year and claim social security entitlements for the remainder of the year, but it is simply inequitable when it applies equally to workers who are without employment for much of the year, have no job security and earn less than average wages over a 12-month period.

On the other hand, Labor understand that there are some casual and contract workers whose circumstances accord with the original rationale for the rule. These workers are fortunate enough to secure reasonably regular highly paid employment which provides them with an above average yearly income and allows them to claim social security benefits for other periods during the year. It is for this reason that we support a modified version of the current proposal which would allow it to meet the original intention of the rule while not penalising those casual workers who have no job security and earn low incomes over the year taken as a whole.

Our suggestion is that casual workers whose average income over the 12 months before claiming a social security benefit is less than the average earnings figure should not be regarded as seasonal workers for the purpose of the act. This would protect any workers who are effectively on low incomes despite having occasional periods of highly paid work. However, it would not protect those who are genuinely high income earners.

This is not just an issue about fairness; it is also about work incentives. It could be argued that casual workers who earn significantly more than average yearly wages in short periods will not be discouraged from doing such work because they will no longer be able to receive benefits. But the situation for casual workers on low yearly incomes is very different, regardless of whether they earn those incomes in relatively short spurts of high paid work. The fact that they will receive less benefit from that work as a result of this disallowable instrument can only reduce the incentive for them to take up that work. The fact that waiver of the waiting period will be considered only if they have virtually no savings from their work would surely make many of these workers wonder what the point of accepting the work might be.

We must not forget the real value of casual work. It not only takes people off welfare dependency in the short term, but it also increases the worker's confidence, skills and overall employability and can lead to further work in the longer term. Perhaps we do not need to encourage people who perform very lucrative work at the same time every year and who have incomes well in excess of what most people earn over an entire year, but for those whose employment prospects are less certain and who have struggled for the most part of the year on low incomes, we must provide every encouragement possible.

In conclusion, we do support moves to restrict access to benefits to those seasonal workers who earn a reasonable income during the year. We supported that when it was proposed, and we continue to support that position, but we are not in favour of cutting benefits to those who are genuinely qualified by virtue of their taking up casual work as it becomes available, even if that is relatively high income work at that particular period. Because of the demand that occurs in our society for specialist skills and the increase in contract work, there are large numbers of workers who do avail themselves of short contract work that may well be reasonably well rewarded but is only available for a short time. We think the government has not done enough to cover the circumstances of all those who may be affected by this measure.

I accept that the disallowance motion is a blunt instrument, but the opposition, through discussion with the government, have been unable to resolve the issue any other way. We would like to see a way through this but, as we have not been able to get the government to come up with a compromise which we think would meet the concerns that we have raised and the government's genuine policy objectives about cutting out those who should not be entitled, we have no option but to move the disallowance.

I have been alerted today that there is some concern from the government about the timing of the measure coming on today. I only point out that it has been on the books since Wednesday, 17 February. I understand there was some communication difficulty, but I have been postponing it for a number of days. We are running out of time to deal with this. It seems to me it is in the government's interest it is dealt with. Anyway, I think that is a minor point. I indicate that there was a problem in communication, and I apologise for that, but it seems to me it has been on the Notice Paper for a considerable period of time. It is important that the matter be resolved and we are keen to do that before Easter.

In moving this disallowance, the opposition think this would at least force the government to reconsider the issues around the sorts of people that I have identified today and ensure that regulations they bring before the parliament do not unfairly impact on people in those circumstances. We accept the need for the general seasonal work rules—we supported them then and we support them now. We are disappointed that the government see fit to seek cheap publicity in the press by accusing us of not supporting those measures, but that is their call.

talk.start.para: —But it is not.

—Well, I read the press, Senator Newman. I do not know where they got it from, but if they did not get it from your office, I would be very surprised. Nevertheless, there is an important public policy issue here, and we urge the Senate to support the disallowance.

—I am speaking on behalf of the Australian Democrats on this disallowance motion, and I must say at the start that I do find it a little difficult understanding exactly what the position of the ALP is on this issue. This measure of penalising seasonal workers who earn above average weekly earnings by making it harder for them to get unemployment benefits or unemployment payments and imposing a longer waiting period on them is one that the Democrats opposed when it was brought in in June last year.

speech.para: The Democrats do not believe it is an appropriate measure for seasonal workers to have a higher hurdle than other workers in terms of waiting periods. For that reason, the Democrats will be supporting this disallowance motion. We believe it will broaden out the number of people who are caught in this measure even further.

In terms of the concerns that Senator Evans was expressing, I am not quite sure, when the Labor Party supported this government measure back in June last year, exactly what they thought would happen with this measure. Who did they think would be affected by it and who did they think would not be? In the second reading debate on the bill back in May last year, I expressed the Democrats' opposition to the proposed changes relating to seasonal workers, and said that they would include such workers as fruit-pickers, shearers, casual teachers and people who perform locum roles in various jobs. It was pretty clear at the time, certainly to the Democrats, that people such as these were likely to get caught up in this measure.

Indeed, as I imagine Senator Newman recalls, probably not half an hour after the bill was actually passed Senator George Campbell, on behalf of the Labor Party, stood up and asked a question in question time which expressed concern about construction workers being affected by this proposed measure, which his own party had supported less than half an hour earlier in this very chamber. Not surprisingly, Senator Newman gave that question fairly short shrift in response.

I found it fairly astonishing at the time that the ALP did support the measure, and I will quote former Senator Neal, who was the spokesperson at the time. I guess that lets Senator Evans off the hook, because it is was not his responsibility, as indeed it was not Mr Swan's responsibility in the other place, either; it was the responsibility of the previous spokespersons for the ALP. But Senator Neal at the time said:

The opposition does believe it is appropriate to take into account the income of those who may have up and down periods because of seasonal work. We do not agree with the Democrats' view that those particular people should be omitted from the income testing . . .

I should hasten to add that that is not actually our view. Our view is that they should have the same income testing as everybody else. Seasonal workers, broadly speaking, are not likely to be better off than people who have permanent jobs. Whilst I am sure there is a very small proportion of people who get huge amounts of money and are able to spend the rest of the year living in luxury—and I think it would be a very small proportion of people—I do not see how, firstly, you can determine a measure which separates out those people from other people who are just getting seasonal, casual or locum work where they can. Clearly, a lot of these sorts of jobs occur in rural and regional areas—not all of them, but a reasonable proportion of them.

The Democrats and I think most parties certainly espouse the need to encourage employment in regional areas. We have had issues in recent times of illegal non-residents being caught working as fruit-pickers in parts of Australia and the people who employ them saying that they cannot find people to do those jobs. I do not know how difficult it is to find fruit-pickers in various areas—obviously it is easier in some areas than in others. But measures such as this which actually penalise people further and make them face an extra waiting period or an extra test before they can access income support obviously are not going to provide an extra incentive for those sorts of people to engage in such work.

The determination we are debating at the moment which it is proposed be disallowed—and I reiterate that the Democrats support that disallowance—extends the seasonal work waiting period to a huge range of industries, such as managers, administrators, professionals, associate professionals, tradespersons, clerical and sales and service workers, production and transport workers and labourers and related workers. That is a pretty wide range of people and, certainly, I think you would be hard pressed to say that a lot of those people are somehow or other getting away with something unfair—rorting the system or living the high life or whatever might be implied. I think the very vast proportion of those people who will be caught up in this measure are simply people who are trying to get work where they can and are not likely to be in what would be called a high income bracket over a prolonged period of time. Certainly all of those people—and that will include people who are in lower income brackets—will clearly be caught by this measure. It is for that reason that the Democrats opposed it initially and why we maintain a consistent position in opposing this determination.

I believe the opposition suggests that this determination represents a substantial departure from the original rationale for the rule as it is no longer aimed at workers who are routinely engaged in extremely lucrative employment. I do not see anything in the wording of the act or in the original speech—or for that matter in anything when the matter initially came up—that suggests it is significantly different from what is contained in this determination, that it does represent a substantial departure. I think it is a broadening—somewhat more than one might have interpreted from the wording of the act, but it is certainly not what I would call a substantial departure. I would see it as an unhelpful broadening, perhaps catching even more people than one might have anticipated from an initial reading of the act.

I cannot see how the opposition see it as being something massively different from what they initially agreed to when this measure was put into law in June last year. It does baffle me. Casual teachers, as indeed the construction workers who Senator George Campbell provided as an example in his question not long after the bill went through, are examples of people who are clearly going to be potentially caught by this measure. They are absolutely, definitely caught by this measure under this determination in terms of labourers and professionals. Again, I just cannot see how this is seen as somehow or other being a massive departure from what was initially intended. I guess in that sense I would probably understand if there was a little perplexity or frustration from the government.

talk.start.para: —The people in this are not seasonal.

—The act defines seasonal work as the Senate applied it—that work that is intermittent and is determined to be seasonal or that is available at approximately the same time or times every year for part or parts only of the year. And I think that sort of thing can easily be interpreted by the department. It is a pretty broad definition which gives a lot of room for interpretation. Again using examples such as teachers, it would be quite easy to say that it occurs at similar times of the year—it occurs at the times of the year when school is in, not at the times of the year when school is out.

speech.para: The other issue is that there is no specific original indication, either in the original measure or in this determination, that it was somehow or other targeting people in extremely lucrative employment. It was targeting anyone who earned anything over average weekly earnings, despite the fact that they only earned that money for a proportion of the year. By definition, seasonal work or non-permanent, regular casual work is work that is not going to bring in an income all year round unless people are able to bounce directly from one job to the next. Those people are often in a more difficult situation, as I said previously, than permanent workers. To suggest that somehow or other they are getting away with more than everybody else is something that the Democrats find fairly baffling.

It is a measure the Democrats did not support when it came in. For that reason we certainly do not support any determination that extends in any way the measure. It is one that we believe should not be there in the first place. We believe it is just another in a string of enforced poverty measures that we have seen over the past few years, basically requiring people to provide their own personal unemployment insurance from their earnings when they get casual or regular seasonal work. There are plenty of other measures—existing income and assets tests and the taxation system—which apply to people when they earn a significant amount of money.

To catch the very small number of people who are somehow earning a fortune in a very short time, we are, through this measure and the initial inclusion of it in the act, catching a lot of people who could not possibly be seen to be earning lucrative amounts of money. It is something we found difficult to see a justification for initially and we certainly do not see any now. For that reason the Democrats will support the disallowance. I do wish the extent of the concerns that the ALP see now were realised at the time the measure was put into law in June last year—then we would not be having this debate now.

talk.start.para: —Once again this chamber is being held to ransom by what can only be now termed the wholly-owned subsidiary of the union movement—the Australian Labor Party. In the past few weeks we have had a plethora of motions from the other side designed to reassure their former masters—and I have to say `former masters' because 67 per cent of Labor senators have come up through the union ranks. I have nothing against that as a legitimate career path, but it does seem a bit excessive when 67 per cent of a group here are former union officials. It would pay the Labor Party to look very carefully at their preselections and perhaps preselect people with some broader experience who are not as likely to kowtow to their former masters.

speech.para: While I usually find the posturing of Labor Party members on the other side who are at the beck and call of the unions pathetic, I find today's disallowance motion from Senator Evans particularly odious. This disallowance is designed to advantage highly unionised, highly privileged workers against less unionised and less privileged workers. That is what is happening today. Let me say it again: it is a disallowance motion designed to advantage highly unionised, highly privileged workers against less unionised and less privileged workers. The ALP has caved in under pressure from the CFMEU. The CFMEU includes workers who are able to negotiate lucrative short-term contracts—often in the construction industry or in industries where they have a contract they can undertake over a limited period of time and earn substantial amounts of money. Let us be very clear: the instrument the opposition is moving to disallow is designed to block access to unemployment payments for people who earn high incomes for parts of the year then spend or dispose of their income in some way to avoid the liquid assets test.

What Labor do not understand, if I am being kind, or what they do not want to understand, if I am being less kind, is that for work to be classed as intermittent or seasonal it must fulfil three criteria. The first criterion is that it must be for less than 12 months. The second criterion is that it must be performed by a person who has been engaged to do a specific project or task or for a set period. The third criterion is that, if the work is performed by a person who accrues leave entitlements, it will not be classified as seasonal work and hence will not be affected by the initiative. All three of these criteria—not one of them; all three of them—must be satisfied for the work to be classified as seasonal. Most work performed by part-time or casual employees will not be affected by the seasonal worker initiative because most casual or part-time workers are not receiving the high incomes that would affect their unemployment payments.

Labor have continually refused to understand the simple truth that this is a fair measure. They have sought to misguide, mislead and misinform the Australian public about the true effect of this measure. The real question today is: why should anyone who earns over $100,000 on a six-month contract be able to spend the money and then claim a holiday at the taxpayers' expense for the next six months? It is totally unacceptable.

It is important to remember that workers who are unemployed prior to taking up employment can remain registered for newstart allowance for up to six fortnights after commencing work, even though their income would preclude them for payment. The formula for calculating the preclusion period provided in legislation ensures that only those workers earning more than average weekly ordinary time earnings will be affected. This disallowable instrument determines only the kind of intermittent work that is to be treated as if it were seasonal. The length of the preclusion period is calculated according to a formula based on the average weekly ordinary time earnings last published by the ABS in the calendar year prior to claim. Currently this amount is $736.70 per week. We are saying that single people earning less than $736.70 a week or $1,473.40 per fortnight will not have a waiting period applied.

For the opposition to come in here and say they are talking about people on low incomes is a nonsense. Let me say that again: single people earning less than $736.70 a week or $1,473.40 a fortnight will not have a waiting period applied. Couples earning less than $1,473.40 a week or $2,946.80 a fortnight will not have the waiting period applied. I ask honourable senators, particularly the Democrats and the Greens, to think about that. The Labor Party cannot come in here and say that this is affecting people on low incomes; it is not. We are saying that people who have similar incomes over a period of time ought to be treated the same.

When we came into government we found that—and we knew about this when we were in opposition—a lot of the social security benefits were riddled with anomalies associated with older people on the pension and people receiving unemployment benefits. To be fair, we need to treat people in similar circumstances with similar incomes in the same way for the purposes of receiving benefits. I think most fair-minded Australians would agree.

The ALP's alternative proposal is that intermittent workers' income should be calculated over a 12-month period and that the worker would be treated as a seasonal worker only if the income was more than an average income, that is, average weekly ordinary time earnings, for the year. This would create a gross inequity in the treatment of seasonal and intermittent workers. Intermittent workers would be treated far more generously than seasonal workers. Of course, many of those seasonal workers are less likely to be unionised than intermittent workers. What we are seeing is that these people would be treated quite differently and unfairly. For example, a single person receiving newstart for six months and then earning $30,000 for six months work would have total earnings in the 12 months prior to the claim of around $34,000, which is lower than average weekly earnings for a year. If the person had been engaged in seasonal work, they would have a preclusion period of 14 weeks, whereas if the ALP's proposal was adopted and they had been doing intermittent work such as contract work, they would not be precluded at all. I cannot see how you can justify that. I know you are frowning, Senator Evans.

talk.start.para: —I do not understand you.
—You might not understand. If you cannot understand what I am saying then I feel sorry for you, but what I am saying is right. Maybe you have been misinformed by someone from the lower house.
—Mr Swan's office. He was given the detail.

—He was given that detail. It is a clear demonstration that these two different groups of people would be treated totally differently. If that is what your party wants, you have been hoodwinked, or should I say you have become a party to what the unions want, because these intermittent workers are more likely to be union members than seasonal workers.
—That's not right.

—It is right. And it is right that people with a similar income are going to be treated differently if you disallow this. I do not know how the ALP can tolerate the inequity. If you are not sure about this, maybe you should withdraw from this and be briefed properly so that you can actually make sure that you are not treating people unfairly. I can tell you that some of those seasonal workers will be pretty upset about what the Labor Party is doing—
—What?

—Senator Margetts, what is happening in this situation is that you have two groups of people who are employed differently in different operations. There are intermittent workers who have a job they have been asked to do under the three conditions I talked about, and/or the job finishes at a certain time, and they earn a certain amount of money. Another group are seasonal workers, and they are treated differently, if you go along with this. What you are doing is creating inequality between two groups of workers because they happen to work in different industries or happen to work under different arrangements. In fact, you will find that some people on reasonably high incomes—I am not saying high incomes—will be eligible for benefits and seasonal workers on less will not be eligible for benefits. Is that correct, Senator Newman?
—Yes.

—So I do not know how the ALP can protect some classes of workers over others. It seems very strange to me. I suppose it is also not interested in requiring those on higher incomes to put their money aside to provide for themselves, because there is an incentive there to actually spend it and to receive benefits. If the ALP was genuinely concerned about fairness and equity, it would withdraw this disallowance motion. Senator Evans over there is looking very perplexed, and I can understand why.
—I do not know what you are talking about.

—You might not know what I am talking about but I know what I am talking about, and I know that if you continue with this disallowance motion you will be ensuring that two groups of workers will be treated differently—
—That is what you are doing.

—People who are intermittent workers will be treated far more generously than seasonal workers. That is what the effect of what you are doing today will be. If that is what you want to do, go out and defend that, but I think you will be defending the indefensible. If the ALP was genuinely concerned with fairness and equity, it would withdraw this disallowance motion.

—I listened to Senator Patterson's contribution, but she said the same thing over and over again and unfortunately did not actually defend the government's case at all, in my opinion. What we are talking about is a determination which would extend the definition of seasonal work well beyond the intent of the seasonal work provisions of the Social Security Act. If the government want to do that then they should come to the Senate with legislation which can be the subject of scrutiny and amendment by the Senate. Again and again Senator Patterson's contribution was that we should treat all workers the same. Quite clearly, the government are not treating all workers the same. In this particular case I guess what they are saying is, `We are treating one group of workers, seasonal workers, badly and we would like to treat all workers just as badly as we are treating seasonal workers.' That is not a particularly good strategy, as far as I am concerned.

speech.para: The act defines seasonal work as, and I paraphrase, work that is available at approximately the same time or times every year for part or parts only of the year, or work that is intermittent and is determined, by disallowable instrument, to be seasonal work. The second part of the definition does not, however, give free rein to the government to call anything it likes seasonal work. It is intermittent work that is referred to. This determination would extend it to include almost any short-term, occasional, one-off period of work for which an individual was paid more than average weekly earnings. This goes well beyond the commonsense understanding of seasonal work, which is usually identified with activities such as crayfishing or shearing.

Coming at this sort of change by a determination is an underhand way of bringing in changes which have the potential to impact quite extensively on potential recipients of a wide variety of social security payments, including newstart allowance, youth allowance, parenting payment or partner allowance. In effect, it begins to treat all kinds of casual and contract workers in virtually every industry as seasonal workers, and its impact extends from managers and professionals to labourers and production workers. The extension of the definition of seasonal work particularly impacts on the waiting period—the period before benefits can be paid. It is during this period that people in need of assistance are most vulnerable to hardship.

Given the sorts of changes we are seeing in the nature of employment across the board, this particular change will affect more and more workers. Work is becoming much more impermanent. Casual work is more common. Short-term contracts are becoming the norm. It is not unusual nowadays for workers to have a relatively short period of highly paid work after being out of work for a considerable time. This does not actually mean that those people need to eat less during the times of unemployment. It does not necessarily mean that somehow these people are automatically rorting the system. It does not mean that these people should be considered to be people who are cheating the system. That is basically what this government is doing.

The work comes along and people pay off the debts that they may have accumulated. They manage okay for a few weeks but they do not necessarily have the capacity to put away the sorts of savings that someone permanently on that income would do. In short, they might not be in any position to support themselves or their family for any extended waiting period before being able to access benefits. The appropriate way to deal with this kind of situation would be to average out people's total income over the previous 12 months. If they were still over average weekly earnings, it might be appropriate to have waiting periods.

But the current proposal makes no such allowance. People in short-term employment will be exposed to waiting periods which, in some instances, could actually be longer than those of people who have lost permanent employment. Instead of a waiting period equivalent to their accrued annual leave—usually four weeks—casual workers who are treated as seasonal may have to wait considerably longer. For a worker who had, say, four months work after a long period of unemployment, this delay could easily be two months or more.

Constantly we were hearing from Senator Patterson that we on this side of the chamber were talking about supporting the union. The reality is, as Senator Evans interjected on several occasions, that the figures do not back this up. The level of union membership amongst casual workers is—as Senator Patterson could find out if she checked—very low.

People will also be disadvantaged by the tougher rules on exemption from the waiting period that usually applies to seasonal work. I know it is difficult for the coalition to understand that we on this side of the chamber might actually be doing this because it is the right and fair thing to do, not because we are necessarily instructed by a particular interest group. If workers or the people out in the community are concerned about this, they have a legitimate right to be heard.

Whereas the former permanent worker can have $2,500 in the bank before the liquid assets test applies, the casual worker—the worker you want to pretend is a seasonal worker—cannot get any reduction in waiting period even if they have as little as $323 in savings. So what we are doing? We are making sure that people are actually turned away from taking up any work opportunities. This includes, I would think, some graduates who are desperate to get work in their actual profession. Yes, this might mean that they might get short-term work—consultancy or whatever—at a relatively higher wage package. However, this might also mean that they have to wait a long time before they get other similar experience.

It is no wonder, as the Melbourne Institute showed us today, that the participation rate of students in Australia is reducing in terms of people wanting to go into tertiary education. This is because, as one would have to think, that people are looking into the future and wondering whether or not they are going to be able to use the skills for which they are trained.

The workers we are talking about could well be suffering hardship, in the normal sense of the word, and still not be able to access the hardship provisions which, as far as seasonal work is concerned, are extremely strict. Coming at this sort of change by a determination is, as I said, an underhand way of bringing in changes which have the potential to impact quite extensively on the potential recipients of a wide variety of social security payments. As such, it should be disallowed by the Senate.

I want to bring in another issue. Commonsense would say that in a time of high unemployment, which is what we still have in Australia, you do not make it more difficult for people to participate in the work force. You do not actually penalise people for working for short periods of time. You do not make it so that, somehow or other, there is an assumption that, if you work full time, you are necessarily better or that you get rewarded for that but, if you manage to get short-term work or seasonal work, somehow you are penalised.

The government have to make up their mind whether they are actually on the side of the people in this country who want to work. They often say they are, but here they are penalising people who will take up work for short periods of time or have the opportunity for short periods of time to take up work. It simply makes no commonsense. What they are doing might mean that some people's choice will be not to take up that offer—and that would be very sad in terms of experience, wasted human capital in Australia and the actual implications for people which the government are refusing to see. They are refusing to see that there are real human consequences from the hard-hearted, cold approach that they are taking to anyone who happens to be able to currently access social security payments. Therefore I urge the Senate to support this disallowance.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —First of all, I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate—and I know Senator Evans did advert to this in an indirect way—that Mr Swan from the shadow minister's office actually gave a commitment that there would be one day's warning before debate on the disallowance. They have not met that commitment, and this chamber does work on that sort of level of trust between the parties, I would have hoped.

speech.para: Senator Chris Evans interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You have said you are sorry and I accept your apology, but I thought I had better explain quite why an apology was appropriate.

speech.para: I find, as the Democrats do, that Labor's position on this is quite incredible. Senator Evans has said that their purpose in moving this disallowance is to force the government to reconsider the issues. He also said that they accept the need for general rules and that this is an important public policy issue. The point—as Senator Bartlett said—is that the government has not moved from the legislation which you endorsed. Not only did you endorse it, your frontbencher in this place who represented the shadow minister is on the record in the chamber—in the Hansard—as saying so. We have not moved from that legislation.

The reason for your move is quite clearly evident, Senator Evans, in the chamber at the moment with Senator George Campbell sitting there, giving you his instructions—and that is exactly why. He was embarrassed at the foolish question that he asked in the chamber last year—

talk.start.para: —That's because you told lies.
—I did not tell lies, Senator, and I take great exception to that.

—Mr Acting Deputy Chair, I raise a point of order. I ask that you ask Senator Campbell to withdraw that—and he should not interject from a seat other than his own. He should not interject anyway, because it is disorderly.
—I uphold the point of order. Senator Campbell, you should not interject, full stop. Would you please withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw the remark.

—So the Democrats are at a loss to understand Labor's position. Senator Bartlett acknowledged that the disallowable instrument was not a substantial departure from the legislation. It is important that that be on the record. The sad thing about this is that the CFMEU, and maybe some of the other unions, have seen fit to pressure the Labor Party to change their original position. That is what has to have happened, because we have not moved away from the purpose of the legislation and the debate that took place in the Senate.

speech.para: I think a question of equity between workers is an issue here. Senator Patterson has made that very clear—although Senator Margetts did not like hearing it—more than once. But that is the fact. This legislation and this disallowable instrument are based on the concept, which all governments have acknowledged over the years, that social security is a safety net based on the needs of people. If we have one group of workers who get caught by the legislation and another group who are in similar circumstances who do not, it is not equitable. If all of them have earnings that are above average weekly ordinary time earnings, then they are in the more privileged elements of our society. They are not the people for whom a social security safety net was intended by any government.

It is very clearly demonstrated by an example. In the same industry you can have a fruit-picker caught by the legislation who could have the same amount of income as the packer in the cannery who is packing the fruit that has been picked by the picker. They can both have the same amount of income over the same period. But if the motion for disallowance were to go through, the fruit-picker who is not unionised would be of no concern to the Labor Party. The packer in the cannery who is unionised would be of concern to them. That can be the only reason for the change of position by the ALP on this measure—which they supported, and said so, in the chamber.

Senator Evans also made some comments about teachers. Let me address that question. Quite interestingly, in the legislation—I hold it up for the benefit of the Senate to see what I am talking about—there is schedule 4, `Amendments relating to seasonal workers'. There is a description of seasonal work. There are parts A and B. Under part B, `Work that is intermittent and is determined to be seasonal for the purposes of this act', there are examples. Examples of work in paragraph (a) are fishing, fruit picking, shearing and work in an industry that is subject to Christmas shutdowns. Examples of work that is intermittent are relief teaching and work as a locum. Where were they? We were not hiding anything from anybody. That was there.

Let me make it clear about the teachers. To be included within the scope of this measure, teachers would need to satisfy the following conditions. They would need to be employed for a set period—that is, for less than 12 months. Most of these relief teachers would be employed for a day or two, or for an indefinite period, and so would not serve the preclusion period. They would also be needing to earn more than AWOTI over the period of the work. As Senator Patterson made clear, it is $736 for a single person and $1,473 for couples. In my book, that is a pretty high wage in Australia, yet the Labor Party has gone into bat for people who are earning that.

talk.start.para: —Is that right? $736 for contract work?
—It is $1,473 for a couple.
—Single is $700?
—For contract work in Kalgoorlie, working 14 hours a day. Try and tell them that is good pay.

—I think it is honourable work and I am glad that they have got it, but it is not a justification for them going on a holiday on the taxpayer as soon as they finish it. That is what I would complain about.
—There is unemployment in Australia.
—Of course you can pick and choose when you are in some industries.
—A lot of them are unemployed because they cannot get work.

—I point out that there is yet a third criterion: that they would not have accrued leave entitlements while they were working. Many of them would in fact be accruing leave. So, on a whole lot of scores, I think the ALP have simply caved in to their union mates, who have forced them to change their minds.

speech.para: The reason behind this is to block access to unemployment payments for people who earn high incomes for part of the year. Within the last 12 months the ALP thought that was fair enough and said so in this chamber. To move a disallowance motion claiming that large numbers of casual and part-time workers will be affected by the seasonal workers initiative is ridiculous. It is not so. It will not apply to most casual or part-time workers because most are not receiving the high incomes that would affect their unemployment payments. Most casual and part-time workers will not be receiving the figures that you have just been talking about.
Senator Chris Evans interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Most people are not caught up by it, Senator. It is wrong of you to infer that this is something that is going across the board to a whole lot of people. It is very much confined to relatively few.
—Contract work—$700 a week.

—For it to be classed as intermittent or seasonal, it must fulfil those three criteria that I referred to in the discussion about teachers. For it to be treated as seasonal it must be for less than 12 months; it must be performed by a person who has been engaged to do a specific project or task, or for a set period; and, thirdly, if it is performed by a person who accrues leave entitlements, it will not be classified as seasonal work and hence will not be affected by the initiative. So there are more people who do not get caught by it.

speech.para: Clearly, most work that is performed by part-time or casual employees will not be affected by the initiative. It is sad, because really it means that the ALP is out of touch with the Australian community. Why would anyone who earns over $100,000 on a six-month contract be able to spend the money and then claim a holiday at the taxpayers' expense for the next six months? Senator Evans was complaining before about me using that example. But let me give you some up-to-date information about what has actually been happening.

talk.start.para: —Save it for the press release.
—Senator, I would like you to listen very carefully to how—
—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Evans was listened to in silence. He has done nothing but interject on Senator Newman the whole time. I ask you to call him to order.
—Yes, I have noted, Senator Evans, that the interjection level is exceeding what I think is the normal debating level, so would you come to order, please.

—I would like to give you some examples of people who have been given long preclusion periods. These are from 1 January until about a week ago. A metal worker had earnings of $45,594 with allowable deductions of $500. He is a single man who worked in Western Australia and moved back to Sydney prior to claiming newstart allowance. He started work on 20 August 1998. He ceased working on 8 February this year and he claimed newstart allowance on 2 March this year.
—How much did he earn?
—He earned $45,594.
—Is that Mr Wright?
—I'm sorry, I have got the information from my department. I have no names. You know that I do not invade their privacy.
—I was just checking whether it was Mr Wright.

—I would not make any claim as to who it was. I also inform the Senate of another worker who appears to have been on a construction contract. His earnings were $88,429. He was married and his partner did not work but claimed parenting allowance. He started work earlier than 1 July 1998 and he finished on 23 December, just in time for Christmas, with his $88,429, and he claimed newstart allowance on 1 February. He will have a preclusion period of 29 weeks.

speech.para: The third example I give the Senate is a person in the mining industry involved in several different contracts, a single person with earnings of $34,430. This person claimed on 10 February this year, and his end date will be 22 weeks time on 13 February. In the first three months of the initiative there have been only four cases in which the preclusion period has applied to teachers. Their average preclusion period was 6.75 weeks.

I have some more general information about the first three months of the new arrangements. The number of cases where it appeared that somebody had been doing seasonal work—in other words being coded by Centrelink—was 898. The total number of cases where a preclusion period has been applied has been 106. For hardship, 10 cases were waived. So there has been some discussion here about the coverage of this measure. There has been some discussion also about waiving and hardship. Those are the facts out of the Centrelink administration of the scheme from 1 January to 26 March provided to me by my department from Centrelink.

I do urge the Labor Party to reconsider. Their original position was the right one. It was fair to people who are all in similar kinds of employment, and they were being treated in the same way if they earned the same income. What could be fairer than that? In addition, it is fair to the taxpayer that people who have substantial means until they have served a preclusion period should be expected to look after themselves before they ask their neighbour, the taxpayer, to support them. What ever has happened to the Labor Party? It is just incredible that you would do this somersault, this about-turn—call it what you like. Our legislation and the disallowable instrument were all based on the fair notion that high income earners who know that they will be without income for a period should put some money aside so they can provide for themselves rather than ask the taxpayer for support. Virtually all social security systems around the world have special provisions relating to seasonal workers. This disallowance motion should be opposed.

talk.start.para: —I have listened very carefully to the debate thus far. I particularly understand the points that have been made by the minister, but also I was very interested in what Senator Bartlett was saying and, in particular, what Senator Margetts was saying. I heard Senator Patterson and Senator Evans also. On the balance, I am going to vote for the disallowance. Members of the opposition who have spoken are talking about a situation where they really do not know what the total outcome will be. Already the minister has indicated that there has been no real research done as to the likely effect of this measure on casual workers.

speech.para: I think a figure of $6 million in savings has been suggested. I have heard mention of figures—including figures coming out of Minister Newman's office—which do not necessarily add up. I will not refer to the last occasion when I had my fingers burnt in regard to that area. I point out that there is a growing number of casual employees in the work force at present, and the figure will grow and grow.

One of the reasons for this is the attitude of the current government. Many workers may have low average yearly incomes and no job security—that is, their work is not seasonal, yet you are bringing them into this area. I thought there were four seasons in the year, not an innumerable number of seasons, when we talk about the meaning of `seasonal work'. Many of these people—including fishermen, for example—are seasonal workers, but they know that the job will come around next year. Unless something awful happens to the world, the season will come around next year. You are lumping together all of these other people who are listed as seasonal workers.

The hardship provisions apply, but they are very strict. The liquid asset may be as little as $323.40 for a single newstart allowance claimant to meet the provisions. I believe that if the regulations are not disallowed there could be quite serious effects and, I suppose, unintended consequences. A casual worker should not be treated worse, in this regard, than a permanent worker who is retrenched. The casual worker does not have the advantage of leave and super entitlements. As I mentioned, there are going to be more and more casual workers in the work force.

By disallowing this determination, the Senate will be doing a service not only to those people who will be affected but also to the government. I think the government should take this matter back and discuss it with the parties concerned. I understand that the opposition has suggested certain things to the government which I think the government should thoroughly consider. The government should take this matter back, once it is disallowed, and enter into discussions with the opposition, if they are so sure that the opposition does not understand it, or if they are following the same principles but the practical application of the determination is adverse. I support the motion moved by Senator Evans.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I appreciate the comments made by all senators in contributing to the debate. I want to make a couple of points. Firstly, I acknowledge that Senator Margetts put the case for the measure far better than I did, and I thank her for that. I think she summed up the core issues; Senator Harradine paid due respect to that. She encapsulated the case very well and that was important for the debate.

speech.para: Senator Bartlett spent most of his contribution bagging the Labor Party, as seems to be his wont, but as long as he votes with us, I am prepared to wear it. I do not know what Senator Patterson's contribution was about. She is obviously upset about trade unions in this country. I am obviously off the CFMEU friends list because they did not bother talking to me about this. It seems to me that we are talking about workers who, in my experience, are not unionised. They are generally contract and casual workers who are most vulnerable to exploitation in the workplace. It is far from being a union issue, but it seems to be the preoccupation of the government that that is what this is about.

My only personal experience of people affected by this comes from a couple of representations we received from schoolteachers and one from a discussion I had with a friend who is a metalworker and who has been forced to seek work in the Goldfields because of an inability to get work in Perth. He is caught by this rule. I think he would be a bit shocked that the minister thought he was a high income earner.

The last point made by Senator Harradine is the most important one. The opposition supported the government's original approach to seasonal workers as we thought that was a fair thing to do. It was about excluding people from social security who were, by virtue of their seasonal work, not entitled to it. What we have done is put a proposition to the government that we ought to look at the earnings over the year, make a proper assessment of whether people are entitled to social security support and take a broader view of that, rather than the narrow view that the government takes—that it all depends on what they earn in a short period of time.

The reality of the world is changing. A lot of people are forced, because of unemployment and the changes in the workplace, to take short-term contract work that lacks security and has no predictability to it. They rely on what they earn from that. At times they are forced to fall back on the social security safety net if their earnings over the period are not sufficient to sustain a reasonable lifestyle.

What we have suggested to the government is that, rather than try to bulldoze this measure through, they have a look at a reasonable compromise to get what I suspect we would all agree—bar the Democrats—is a reasonable policy outcome; that is, to find a way in which those that deserve some social security support receive it and those that do not are excluded. I do not think it is beyond the wit of the Senate to do that, but we were not able to get that result from the government. Hence we have to go with, as I described before, this blunt instrument of disallowance. However, this will at least force the government to go back and look at how best we can achieve the right policy outcome. I commend the disallowance motion to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —As was announced earlier, a ballot will be necessary to fill the position on the Select Committee on Information Technologies for an Independent or a Green senator. I understand that now is a convenient time for the ballot to be held.
—I have put myself forward for membership of the Select Committee on Information Technologies and for this ballot because I bring to that committee a very necessary added even hand and open mind.

speech.para: Mr Acting Deputy President, as you will know from the debate a couple of days ago, the terms of reference of the committee have caused some concern to the Greens and indeed the Democrats. But I bring balance, I believe, to the narrowness of the specific terms in paragraph (c) of the committee's terms of reference. As you know, this committee is a re-established one. It sat before and has looked at a wide range of issues regarding information technology.

The committee has been set up again to further the work of previous committees in evaluating the development of self-regulatory codes in the information industries and to monitor the personal, social and economic impact of continuing technological change created by industries and services utilising information technologies. The committee is to inquire into and report on other matters referred to it by the Senate. That, I believe, is a very important purpose.

We have a need in Australia, with the onrush of information technology, to put a priority on such things as the need for all homes to have access to information technology. We must ensure that all students, indeed all schools, are well serviced by information technology. This is a critical matter because we know that many homes and schools in Australia do not have such access.

We also need to look at the impact of this technology on the community at large. Many people feel left out. They feel bewildered by modern information technology. Many Australians are disadvantaged. I would add that the disadvantage in information technology runs fairly roughly along the lines of those who are already poor and those who are already in minority groups—for example, groups for whom English is not their first language.

I will bring an open mind to this committee. In particular, I will be keen to see that the specific term of reference which has led to the establishment of this committee is kept in place. I refer to paragraph (c), which follows upon Senator Alston's announcement of the government's move to establish through, amongst other things, legislation coming before the parliament a means of restricting—without going into the technological terms—what can be shown and purveyed on the Internet, especially matters that encompass pornography.

There is a widespread feeling in the community that this committee is being established to clamp down on what Australians might see, hear or turn to on the Internet. Let me state at this point for the Senate's deliberation that I have concerns that, in particular, gratuitous violence ought to be kept in check. I am totally opposed to any form of entertainment or other transmission which involves the abuse of any person and the infringements of their rights and wellbeing. That said, I am not in the business of following—

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I think you should draw the honourable senator's attention to the relevant standing order. I understand that his remarks should be related to why he should be elected, rather than how the committee should operate.
—I do not uphold the point of order.

—I will not speak for much longer because I know there is some anxiety to have a vote before too long. I refer to the make-up of the committee as it stands. It is a committee of eight. There are already four government appointees. There will be two from the Labor Party and a Democrat. That leaves the vital eighth position to either Senator Harradine, as nominated, or myself.

speech.para: I do not want to speak for Senator Harradine on this, but I think few would argue that he is very much closer to Senator Alston and Mr Howard's point of view—that is, the government's point of view—on regulation of the Internet than I am. Therefore, it would seem, on the face of it, a very good thing to help balance the weight of this committee—not to lead to further imbalance. Already half the committee members represent the government. If Senator Harradine were elected rather than me, it would be five-three. I think the committee would lose an open mind, an inquiring mind, but a very necessary balance to the more narrow viewpoint of Senator Alston and the government appointees. On that ground, it would be judicious of the Senate to put a Green onto this committee.

There is another added ground. Both Senator Harradine and I come from Tasmania and will represent various components of the Tasmania community, but I also have a wide access through the Greens to with the whole of the Australian community. We are a vigorous, forward looking, fresh entity in politics. We are particularly concerned and open about the impact of information technology not just on this generation but on future generations. The words of Ralph Nader, the great consumer advocate who came to Launceston in 1980 during the Franklin Dam debate, are ringing in my ears. He said, `Information is the currency of democracy.' In so far as we trammel information, we trammel democracy. It is very important that we do not stray into unnecessary censoriousness or any close-down of point of view with one citizen putting his or her viewpoint across those of other citizens to censor what they may see, hear, listen to or indeed disseminate.

I am not a regular visitor to the Prime Minister's office. I am not negotiating with, nor will I be indebted to, Senator Alston or to anybody else in the government. Moreover, I have declared my hand on both the sale of more of Telstra and on the GST package. So the government has no tradeable entity with me. I ask the Senate to consider that seriously in this important vote and ensure that Green representation is the outcome.

talk.start.para: —The question is that government amendments Nos 14 and 15 be agreed to.
—I seek leave to withdraw government amendment No. 15 and substitute it with a new amendment No. 15.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move new government amendment No. 15:

speech.para: (15) Schedule 2, item 8, page 19 (lines 7 to 12), omit subsection (5GC), substitute:

(5GC) The employer must give the employee 2 copies of the form completed under subsection (5GA) no later than 14 July in the calendar year after the calendar year in which the employee ceased to be employed by the employer.

Note: For employees described in subsection (5GA), the maximum time between the employee ceasing to be employed by the employer and the employer giving the employee copies of the group certificate will be no longer than 15 months and 2 weeks.

Amendment No. 14 and new amendment No. 15 remove the requirement for employers to issue group certificates earlier than the end of the financial year in cases where the employee will have a fringe benefits amount shown on their group certificate. The existing provision, subsection 221F(5CA) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, allows employees to request an early group certificate if they cease to be employed. Amendment No. 14 removes the requirement for employers to issue an early group certificate where the employee will have a fringe benefits amount shown on their group certificate.

Item 8 of schedule 2 of the bill provides for an additional group certificate to be issued to an employee who leaves employment between 1 April and 30 June where the employee has a reportable fringe benefits amount on or after 1 April. The need for this additional group certificate arises because of the non-alignment of the FBT and income tax years.

Item 8 also includes a provision to allow employees to request an early group certificate if they cease to be employed. In line with amendment No. 14, the new amendment No. 15 removes from item 8 the requirement for an employer to issue an early group certifi cate. Of course, neither of these amendments prevents an employer providing an early group certificate to an employee who has ceased to be employed where the employer is able to calculate the reportable fringe benefits amount. In addition, employees who cease to be employed and who do not receive any fringe benefits, or who receive fringe benefits with a total taxable value of less than $1,000, continue to be able to request an early group certificate.

The amendments have the effect that, for a very small number of employees, the maximum time between the employee ceasing to be employed by the employer and the employer giving the employee copies of the group certificate will be no longer than 15 months and two weeks. Not having the amendments would subject employers to more complex and expensive record keeping systems just to calculate an employee's reportable fringe benefits amount partway through a year.

talk.start.para: —Could I just ask: are there any penalties for a person who chooses not to put in a tax return for up to 15 months and two weeks?

—The answer to Senator Margetts's question is that the group certificate for the year in which they have to lodge their return will be out on 14 July, which will mean they can furnish their return within the law.
